Brief summary of report by The Economist Intelligence Unit

 

Download the PDF from VitaminDWiki
Category Justification
Palliative and healthcare environment This category includes indicators assessing the general palliative and healthcare environment, as well the existence of a well-articulated, effective and widely implemented government strategy.
Human resources Trained specialists, medical professionals and support staff are key in ensuring available services are delivered in a professional and high-quality fashion.
Affordability of care Where care is available, it needs to be affordable. In this category we assess public funding as well as out-of-pocket expenses for accessing palliative care.
Quality of care Quality of care is the most important category in the Index. It assesses various dimensions of quality, including the availability of strong opioid analgesics (morphine and equivalents), monitoring standards in organisations and the availability of services such as psychosocial support for patients and their families.
Community engagement The role of the community is important in palliative care, especially as volunteer workers are vital in the provision of care. In this category, we assess the availability and training for volunteer workers, and public awareness of palliative care.

item.title: Magnesium is associated with better quality of life in COPD, not Vitamin D
item.description:
Serum magnesium and not vitamin D is associated with better QoL in COPD: A cross-sectional study.

Respir Med. 2015 Mar 27. pii: S0954-6111(15)00104-3. doi: 10.1016/j.rmed.2015.03.005. [Epub ahead of print]

Hashim Ali Hussein S1, Nielsen LP2, Konow Bøgebjerg Dolberg M3, Dahl R4.

BACKGROUND:

Deficiency of serum levels of vitamin D3 (se vitD), magnesium (se Mg) and calcium (se Ca) may be associated with increased exacerbation risk in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). However, associations with other aspects of COPD, e.g. lung function and quality of life (QoL), have been studied less extensively.

item.title: Quality of life increased with increased levels of vitamin D
Pure North (Calgary) improves health by raising vitamin D to 60 ng
5000 IU of vitamin D in daily bread resulted in 50 ng and improved quality of life
item.description:
Vitamin d fortified bread improves pain and physical function domains of quality of life in nursing home residents.

J Med Food. 2014 May;17(5):625-31. doi: 10.1089/jmf.2012.0210.

Costan AR1, Vulpoi C c.vulpoi@yahoo.fr, Mocanu V.

1 Department of Endocrinology, Grigore T. Popa University of Medicine and Pharmacy , Iasi, Romania .

Abstract Nursing home residents have severe vitamin D deficiency and increased risk of falls and fractures. These individuals may need 125 μg of vitamin D3 to achieve desirable 25-hydroxyvitamin D [25(OH)D] concentrations to improve overall health. We evaluated health-related quality of life (HRQoL) in 45 nursing home residents (28 women and 17 men, aged 58-89 years) with 25(OH)D concentrations <50 nM who consumed daily one bun that had been fortified with 125 μg vitamin D3. The Romanian version of Questionnaire of the European Foundation for Osteoporosis (QUALEFFO-41) was applied at baseline and after 12 months. Data were analyzed using repeated measures analyses of variance (ANOVA).
